Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Controlling Interfacial Composition to Optimize Fracture Strength in Transient-Liquid-Phase Bonded Ceramics

POR.DRECONTENT:
In a number of high-tech devices, it is desirable to utilize the unique properties of a range of disparate materials. It has long been recognized that the unique wear-, thermal-, and corrosion-resistant properties of ceramics make them attractive for a wide range of applications. However, the inherent brittleness of ceramics has currently limited their widespread use in structural applications due to the danger of catastrophic failure, and the difficulty in forming complex shapes. In order to expand the range of uses for structural ceramics, especially for high-temperature use, we have been developing a technique for joining ceramic components using partial-transient-liquid-phase (PTLP) bonding. PTLP bonding is unique in its ability to form joints with use temperatures at or above the joining temperature.

            The success of PTLP bonding is dependent on the careful selection of the bonding interlayer according to the ceramic that is to be bonded. The interlayer must both adhere strongly to the ceramic, while also having a similar expansion/contraction rate as the ceramic when the unit is heated/cooled. The latter requirement is to ensure that the material does not experience a large amount of internal stress during heating and cooling, which can be severely detrimental to the final strength of the bonded assembly.

            At Kyushu University, interlayer compositions designed to join alumina ceramic were tested to determine their efficacy and better understand the evolution of the bonding process. Sessile wetting experiments, used to determine how easily a molten droplet of metal spreads across a ceramic substrate, and electron probe microanalysis, used to determine the composition of the interlayer across the bond volume, gave insight into why certain interlayer systems are more successful than others. This information has been instrumental in the development of a future template for choosing interlayers to PTLP bond a variety of advanced ceramics.
